awd_titl_txt: Mathematics - Opportunities in Research and Education (MORE)
awd_abstract_narration:
The participation of underrepresented students in mathematical sciences doctoral programs is an issue of national concern. MORE: Mathematics - Opportunities in Research and Education is a new, annual workshop designed to increase the number of these students who pursue graduate degrees in mathematics; develop a peer network for support in continuing education and career goals; and equip participants with strategies to increase retention among those who enter graduate programs in the mathematical sciences. This is achieved through a unique active workshop format engaging students in highly relevant mathematics tied to applications that address societal needs. MORE specifically targets and prioritizes the participation of female, minoritized, and/or first-generation college students, involves them mathematics via experiential learning in a collaborative setting, establishes a peer/mentor community, and provides them with insight on and support for mathematical graduate experiences. The MORE workshop gives participants strength in numbers in ways that mobile their collective promise in mathematics, thus leading to a better qualified and more diverse workforce.

The MORE: Mathematics - Opportunities in Research and Education conference serves as an early professional development and community-building opportunity for undergraduate mathematical sciences majors.  The target audience for the workshop includes women, first-generation college students, and students traditionally under-represented in the mathematical sciences. In addition to helping students build a peer mentoring network, the workshop will introduce students to current research questions introduced by two topical plenary speakers.  These presentations will be followed by working group sessions, where students advance the research question through guided discussion and exploration led by graduate students. Topics are selected for their timeliness and accessibility. Panels and other activities are arranged to demystify the graduate school experience. Graduate students assisting in cooperative breakout sessions will receive mentor training, providing them with translational skills. MORE also provides materials to a larger audience through its Get MORE page, which highlights upcoming opportunities of interest, and the SEGS: Success and Enrichment in Graduate School page, which focuses on topics that are tied to documented barriers to success for the target group of participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The MORE: Mathematics:  Opportunities in Research and Education workshop was designed to encourage first-generation college students and students from under-represented populations in mathematics to continue their education into graduate school by demystifying the graduate school experience.  The workshop includes panel sessions with current graduate students, with mathematicians employed in industry and academia, with graduate coordinators in mathematics departments, and with faculty and industry partners who run undergraduate research programs. 

We recruited eight or nine graduate students to hold the "near to peer" sessions.  We used three to four panelists for each of the other sessions.  

The workshop also hosted two plenary speakers who interact with the participants throughout the weekend.  The plenary speakers create an activity for the students which provides insight into the typical problems in graduate school.

The panels led by the graduate students provide a “near to peer” experience.  None of the involved faculty are in the room during these sessions.  We have two panels running simultaneously, with 3-4 graduate students in each room.  Halfway through the allotted time, we switch the graduate students to ensure the participants hear from a wide range of perspectives.  The sessions are informal, giving participants the freedom to openly discuss the graduate school experience, from application to thesis.

The career panel contains mathematicians from industry and academia, with both master’s and doctoral degrees.  The panelists provide insight on their individual decisions to attend graduate school and describe their normal workday, encouraging students to continue their education to open the possibilities for their upcoming career choices.

The applications panel contains graduate coordinators and department chairs from different programs.  Some of the department chairs are from primarily undergraduate institutions, and they provide insight on the different types of students from their programs who continue into graduate school.  They understand the application process from the developer’s perspective, while the graduate coordinator provides the reviewer perspective.  The coordinators describe the components in the application which they value, and the students learn that the programs are not “one size fits all”.  They are encouraged to explore programs before applying to ensure the programs will help them achieve their ultimate career goals.

The final panel is on internships and REUs.  The panelists provide information on the application process, the types of programs available, and things the students can do if they cannot spend time away from campus to participate in a months-long experience.  For the latter, for instance, students are encouraged to seek out professors on campus who will mentor them in a research project.

The survey responses from those who have attended overwhelmingly show the workshop helped participants understand fundamentals about graduate school and increased the likelihood they would apply to graduate school.  Most participants identified the "near to peer" session with the current graduate students as their favorite component. 

The funding is used to reimburse travel expenses and provide shared meals for the participants.  The travel expense reimbursement is needed for the audience we are targeting.  The shared meal experience allows participants to build their professional peer network and provides a relaxed atmosphere for the participants to continue their exploration of the graduate school process.  We have found these interactions make the students more comfortable asking questions of the speakers and panelists, and it allows them time to communicate with one another and realize they are all seeking answers to the graduate school question.

Our recommendations for building such a workshop would include incorporation of a “near to peer” session which allows for group discussion (i.e., not a poster session), shared meals, and engaging plenary speakers who can help them relate to the graduate research component.  The other panels were also beneficial; we had better success in recruiting panelists when they could participate virtually.  This limited the interaction with participants, however.

While the virtual workshops were a valid option during the COVID-19 pandemic, the in-person event better achieves our goals.  Overall, we believe a fully engaged weekend with the participants, without a direct recruiting pitch for a particular graduate program, gives them the opportunity to get the most important questions they have about graduate education answered.
